column1: English: Ok, I'm not sure we need paramedics, but let's give it a go. = French: OK, je ne suis pas sûre que nous ayons besoin des secours, mais on peut essayer. ### French: Les secours sont les agents capables de faire bouger l'ascenseur jusqu'à un étage et de faire ouvrir les porte pour nous libérer. = English:

column3: Can you help me please?

column1: English: When you were born here, it's difficult to go to another country. = French: Quand on est né ici, c'est difficile d'aller dans un autre pays. ### French: On y perd tous ses repères. = English:
column2: You lose your bearings entirely.
column3: You lose all your references.

column1: English: I usually take the stairs but was feeling lazy today! = French: D'habitude je prends les escaliers, mais j'ai eu la flemme aujourd'hui. ### French: Moi aussi, mais comme je suis très chargée, j'ai pris l'ascenseur et je le regrette d'autant plus que je suis moi aussi attendue et que mon portable n'a pas de réseau. = English:
column2: Me too, but as I'm very weighed down, I took the lift and I'm regretting it, especially as they're expecting me too, and my mobile doesn't have any signal.
column3: Me too, but as I was very busy, I took the elevator and I regret it even more as I am also expected and my mobile phone has no network.

column1: English: Shall we have it at home? = French: On fait ça à la maison ? ### French: Si tu veux! = English:
column2: If you want!
column3: If you want!

column1: French: Non, c'est la première fois de ma vie que je joue à ce jeu ! = English: No, it's the first time in my life I've played this game. ### French: Après, cela fait des années maintenant que j'habite en Islande. = English:
column2: Then again, I've been living in Iceland for years now.
column3: After, it's been years now that I live in Iceland.

column1: French: Raconte-moi. = English: Tell me about it. ### French: Que s'est-il passé ? = English:
column2: What happened?
column3: What happened?

column1: French: Il va y avoir un enterrement de vie de garçon dans le bar ce soir ? = English: So there's going to be a stag do in the bar tonight? ### French: cela risque d'être bien animé ! = English:
column2: That could get lively!
column3: it might be a lively night!

column1: French: J'ai besoin d'un pansement. = English: I think I need a plaster. ### French: Mais tu t'es coupé tout le doigt ! = English:
column2: But you've cut your finger off!
column3: But you cut your whole finger!

column1: French: Ceci dit, la nourriture n'est pas excellente. = English: The food though is not very good. ### French: Oui c'est le souvenir que j'avais pour la nourriture. = English:
column2: Yes, that's what I remember about the food.
column3: Yes, that's the memory I have of the food.

column1: English: Oh! = French: Ah! ### French: On a décollé et vous ne l'avez même pas remarqué. = English:
column2: We've taken off and you didn't even notice.
column3: We

column1: French: Je suis désolé. = English: I'm sorry ### French: Bon tant pis. = English:
column2: Ok, never mind.
column3: Well, that's too bad.

column1: French: Oh oui, très bonne idée. = English: Ah yes, very good idea. ### French: Ça fait au moins un quart d'heure que je ne l'ai pas vue, elle me manque! = English:
column2: It's been at least 15 minutes since I last saw her. I miss her.
column3: I haven't seen her for at least 15 minutes, I miss her!

column1: English: I wanted to say I'm thinking we might be going round in circles! = French: Je voulais dire que je pense que nous tournons en rond ! ### French: Une question, Sandra : portez-vous des lunettes = English:
column2: One question, Sandra: do you wear glasses?
column3: A question, Sandra : do you wear glasses?

column1: English: Difficult to choose. = French: Difficile de choisir. ### French: Personnellement j'opterai pour des tranches d'ananas flambées à l'armagnac. = English:
column2: Personally I would go for pineapple slices flambéed in Armagnac.
column3: Personally I would opt for slices of pineapple flambéed with armagnac.

column1: French:  = English:  ### French: Hey, let's go swimming :) = English:
column2: Hey, let's go swimming :)
column3: Hey, let's go swimming :)

column1: French: Par contre j'ai beaucoup d'eau, nous pourrons survivre encore quelques temps. = English: But I do have lots of water. We can still survive for some time. ### French: Tu as ton smartphone avec toi ? = English:
column2: Do you have your smartphone on you?
column3: Do you have your smartphone with you?

column1: French: Il faut continuer un peu le long de l'étang puis remonter la rivière pendant une centaine de mètres. = English: You have to keep going along the pond and then head up the river for about a hundred metres. ### French: Après, il y a ce rond-point et vous ne pourrez pas le rater. = English:
column2: After that, there's a roundabout and then you can't miss it.
column3: After that, there is this roundabout and you will not miss it.

column1: French: Bon, je vais réfléchir à la déco et on se rappelle avant la fête. = English: Ok, I'll think about the decorations and let's call each other before the party. ### French: Merci pour ton aide! = English:
column2: Thanks for your help!
column3: Thank you for your help!

column1: French: Oui, vous devriez trouver le madère dans le placard de droite. = English: Yes you should find the madeira in the right hand cupboard. ### French: Ah oui pardon. = English:
column2: Ah yes, sorry.
column3: Ah yes, sorry.

column1: French: Ne vous inquiétez pas, mais faites en sorte de savoir où sont les choses demain. = English: Don't worry, but make sure you know what's what tomorrow, ### French: Oui chef. = English:
column2: Yes chef.
column3: Yes, sir.

column1: French: Le voilà, je vous le donne. = English: Here it is - I'll give it to you. ### French: Pendant ce temps, j'appelle l'école pour les prévenir que je vais être un peu en retard = English:
column2: In the meantime, I'll call the school to let them know I'm going to be a bit late.
column3: While I'm on the phone, I'll call the school to let them know that I'll be a little late.

column1: English: Ok, it can't really make it any worse than it already is, and it's not good for him to be inside all day! = French: OK, ça ne peut pas vraiment empirer la situation et ce n'est pas bon pour lui de rester toute la journée à l'intérieur. ### French: Tu plaisante, c'est un chien d'appartement, quand j'ai voulu le sortir sous la pluie il ne voulait pas sortir, il a tout juste mis le nez dehors, fait pipi à l'angle de la maison et il tirait déjà sur sa laisse pour rentrer. = English:
column2: You're joking. It's a house dog. When I wanted to take him out in the rain, he didn't want to go out - he just stuck his nose outside, peed by the corner of the house and tugged on his lead to go back home.
column3: You are joking, he is an apartment dog, when I wanted to take him out in the rain he didn't want to go out, he just put his nose out, peed at the corner of the house and was already pulling on his leash to go back inside.

column1: French: Ça représentait une fortune. = English: It was a fortune. ### French: Ça a ruiné l'économie allemande, et a conduit indirectement à la seconde guerre mondiale. = English:
column2: It ruined the German economy and indirectly led to the second world war.
column3: It ruined the German economy, and indirectly led to the second world war.

column1: English: Electronic devices contain a number of toxic substances, for example in the batteries, screen and processors. = French: Les appareils électroniques contiennent de nombreux produits toxiques, par exemple dans les batteries, les écrans, les processeurs. ### French: Je pense notamment aux semi-conducteurs, qui sont presque exclusivement produits en Chine, dans des mines très polluantes. = English:
column2: I am thinking in particular of semi-conductors, which are almost exclusively produced in China, in highly polluting mines.
column3: I am thinking in particular of semiconductors, which are almost exclusively produced in China, in very polluting mines.

column1: French: Comme tu es à la maison maintenant, je suppose que tu as réussi à faire réparer la voiture ? = English: As you're now home, I'm assuming that you managed to get the car fixed? ### French: non j'ai dû rentrer à pied = English:
column2: No, I had to walk home.
column3: no I had to walk home

column1: English: It is going to be a lot of fun = French: On va bien s'amuser. ### French: oui, tu as le bon RDV, je te le confirme. = English:
column2: Yes, you have the right meeting, that's correct.
column3: yes, you have the right appointment, I confirm it.

column1: French: Je préfère aller profiter de l'eau et me rafraichir = English: I prefer to make the most of the water and cool down a bit. ### French: mais accompagne moi ! = English:
column2: But do join me!
column3: but come with me!

column1: French: Vous devez constituer des groupes de trois élèves = English: You must form groups of three students. ### French: et préparer ensemble une expérience de chimie à présenter par oral aux autres élèves = English:
column2: And together prepare a chemistry experiment to present orally to the other students.
column3: and prepare together a chemistry experiment to present orally to the other students.

column1: French: Je ne sais pas où commencer. = English: I don't know where to begin. ### French: Alors commençons par des questions simples. = English:
column2: So let's start with simple questions.
column3: So let's start with simple questions.

column1: French: Nous n'avons pas, selon eux, répondu à toutes leurs exigences techniques. = English: According to them, we didn't meet all their technical demands. ### French: de plus, nous étions trop cher = English:
column2: And we were too expensive.
column3: in addition, we were too expensive

column1: English: We're going to crash miserably in the middle of the ocean.  = French: On va s'écraser lamentablement en plein milieu de l'océan. ### French: On sera réduits en miettes, à plusieurs kilomètres sous l'eau. = English:
column2: We'll be ripped to shreds, several kilometres underwater.
column3: We're going to be reduced to tiny pieces, several kilometers under the water.

column1: French: Je vais réfléchir à la liste des invités. = English: I'll think about the guest list. ### French: Je dois te laisser pour l'instant, mais merci pour tous tes conseils! = English:
column2: I have to go now, but thank you for your advice!
column3: I have to let you go for now, but thank you for all your advice!

column1: French: On voit des films, on participe à des jeux, il y a une bibliothèque... = English: We watch films, play games, there's a library... ### French: Et les repas sont assez bons. = English:
column2: And the meals are quite good.
column3: And the food is quite good.

column1: French: Peut-être que ce so t des œufs de poissons enom = English: Perhaps they are eggs from enorm... fish ### French: Désolée une erreur = English:
column2: Sorry a mistake.
column3: Sorry, an error

column1: French: Il est jeune, mais ça n'excuse pas son égoïsme. = English: He's young, but that's no excuse for his selfishness. ### French: Et surtout, cette relation vous faisait du mal. = English:
column2: And most importantly, the relationship was hurting you.
column3: And above all, this relationship was hurting you.

column1: English: Oh sorry, I didn't see you there. Good evening, sir! = French: Oh désolé, je vous ai mal vu, bonsoir monsieur! ### French: Il n'y a pas beaucoup de lumière, et, de dos, vos cheveux longs m'ont induit en erreur. = English:
column2: There isn't much light in here, and from behind your long hair threw me off.
column3: There isn't much light, and, from behind, your long hair made me think you were a woman. = German: Es ist nicht viel Licht, und, von hinten, Ihre langen Haare haben mich verwirrt.

column1: English: That's giving me lots of ideas for decorations and costumes! = French: En fait, ça me donne plein d'idées de décoration et de costumes! ### French: Ah, il faudra que tu me le présentes! = English:
column2: Ah, you must introduce him to me!
column3: Ah, you'll have to introduce me to him! = German: Ah, du musst mir ihn vorstellen!

column1: English: I'd like to play a card game. = French: Je veux bien jouer à un jeu de cartes. ### French: Cela m'occupera l'esprit = English:
column2: It'll help take my mind off it.
column3: It will keep my mind occupied.

column1: French: Oui moi aussi, pour être honnête. = English: Me too to be honest. ### French: Si on doit rester ici encore longtemps, vous pouvez travailler. = English:
column2: If we have to stay here any longer, you could work.
column3: If we have to stay here for a long time, you can work.

column1: French: Oui bien sûr. = English: Yes of course. ### French: Juste en face il y a le cabinet du Dr Jekyll, c'est un excellent diététicien. = English:
column2: Just opposite is Dr. Jekyll's surgery. He's an excellent nutritionist.
column3: Just across the road is Dr Jekyll's surgery, he's an excellent dietitian.

column1: French: Je ne sais pas dans quelle mesure c'est de votre faute, mais si on reste coincés longtemps dans cet ascenseur, vous pourrez y travailler ici. = English: I don't know how much it's your fault, but if we're stuck in this lift a long time, you could work in here. ### French: Je vous que vous avez votre ordinateur avec vous, c'est parfait. = English:
column2: You've got your computer with you, I see. It's perfect.
column3: I hope you have your computer with you, that's perfect.

column1: French: Que voulez-vous qu'on fasse ? = English: What do you want us to do? ### French: Même si ça tombe mal, il vaut mieux ça plutôt que ce soit l'ascenseur qui tombe ! = English:
column2: Even if it falls at a bad time, better that than the lift falling!
column3: Even if it is bad timing, it is better that it is the elevator that falls!

column1: French:  = English:  ### French: Je ne suis pas sûr que ces canards vont aimer notre vieux pain = English:
column2: I'm not sure these ducks are going to like our old bread.
column3: I am not sure that these ducks will like our old bread

column1: French: Ne t'approche pas trop ! = English: Don't get too near! ### French: C'est vraiment un bel endroit. = English:
column2: It's really a beautiful place.
column3: It's a really nice place.

column1: English: On no, don't worry. It's not your fault! = French: Oh non ne t'inquiète pas, ce n'est pas de ta faute ! ### French: Je me demande ce qui a bien pu se passer, nous nous sommes peut-être trompées sur la commande .... = English:
column2: I wonder what could have happened. Perhaps we got the order wrong...
column3: I wonder what happened, we might have made a mistake with the order...

column3: OK.
